<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 507, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 285]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 286, 539, 317]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 847, 729, 864]]<|/det|>
This document has 16 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In order to determine the period of a pendulum, a student times one complete swing of the pendulum using an analogue stop-watch with a second hand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 732, 135]]<|/det|>
Which change of method produces the greatest improvement in accuracy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 146, 134, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 714, 163]]<|/det|>
asking a friend with a shorter reaction time to take the measurement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 171, 134, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 170, 756, 189]]<|/det|>
measuring the time for 100 swings of the pendulum and dividing it by 100

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 198, 134, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 197, 710, 216]]<|/det|>
measuring the time for a half swing of the pendulum and doubling it

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 224, 134, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 224, 316, 242]]<|/det|>
using a digital timer

<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 653, 920, 687]]<|/det|>
When a diver swims down from the surface of the water to a depth of \(10\mathrm{m}\), the pressure experienced increases from \(100 000\mathrm{N / m}^2\) to \(200 000\mathrm{N / m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 698, 546, 717]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 727, 532, 745]]<|/det|>

The temperature of X is \(50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) and the temperature of Y is \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 643, 137]]<|/det|> The two blocks are placed in contact with each other, as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 144, 628, 222]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 234, 593, 252]]<|/det|> After some time, both blocks have a temperature of \(25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 264, 591, 282]]<|/det|> What has happened to the internal energy of each block? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 294, 504, 440]]<|/det|>

The arrowed line from X to Y is the path of the convection current in the air. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 508, 688, 682]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 692, 779, 711]]<|/det|> Which row about the air temperature and the air density at X and at Y is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 722, 526, 852]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 183, 393, 202]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[774, 183, 795, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[803, 183, 887, 202]]<|/det|>
Which quantities relating to a wave on the surface of water can both be measured in metres?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 243, 138, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 255, 359, 273]]<|/det|>
amplitude and frequency

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 798, 131, 816]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 798, 630, 816]]<|/det|> Any sound a dog can hear can also be heard by a human. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 824, 131, 843]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 824, 630, 843]]<|/det|> Any sound a human can hear can also be heard by a dog. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 851, 131, 870]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 851, 730, 870]]<|/det|> Dogs can hear some low frequency sounds that are silent for humans. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 878, 131, 895]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 878, 737, 895]]<|/det|> Dogs can hear some high frequency sounds that are silent for humans.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 288, 107, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 621, 307]]<|/det|> Object 1 is given a negative charge and placed on a balance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 319, 920, 354]]<|/det|> Object 2, which is also charged, is brought close to object 1 and the reading on the balance changes as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 358, 865, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 501, 655, 520]]<|/det|> Which action would further decrease the reading on the balance? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 530, 134, 549]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 530, 569, 549]]<|/det|> Add the same number of electrons to both objects. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 558, 133, 575]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 556, 626, 575]]<|/det|> Remove the same number of electrons from both objects. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 584, 133, 602]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 583, 512, 602]]<|/det|> Transfer electrons from object 1 to object 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 610, 133, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 609, 512, 628]]<|/det|> Transfer electrons from object 2 to object 1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 653, 104, 670]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 653, 500, 670]]<|/det|> Which statement about a voltmeter is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 681, 134, 699]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 681, 534, 700]]<|/det|> It has a scale which is marked in amperes (A). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 707, 133, 725]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 707, 500, 725]]<|/det|> It must be connected in series in a circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 734, 133, 752]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 734, 467, 752]]<|/det|> It measures potential difference (p.d.). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 761, 133, 778]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 761, 390, 778]]<|/det|> It must have three terminals.

The rod becomes positively charged because of the movement of charged particles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 392, 870, 409]]<|/det|> Which row gives the name of these charged particles and the direction in which they move? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 520, 567]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 191, 353, 209]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 265, 104, 284]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 265, 698, 284]]<|/det|>
A teacher sets up the equipment for three demonstrations, P, Q and R.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 291, 920, 640]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 661, 554, 680]]<|/det|>
In demonstration P, the magnet is moved to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 691, 452, 709]]<|/det|>
In demonstration Q, the switch is closed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 720, 641, 739]]<|/det|>
In demonstration R, the copper rod is moved vertically upwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 750, 764, 769]]<|/det|>
Which demonstrations can be used to demonstrate electromagnetic induction?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 778, 133, 797]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 778, 751, 797]]<|/det|>
P and Q only B P and R only C Q and R only D P, Q and R

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A metal rod PQ rests on two horizontal metal wires that are attached to a battery. The rod lies between the poles of a magnet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 114, 745, 344]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 351, 559, 371]]<|/det|>
When the switch is closed, the rod moves to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 381, 589, 400]]<|/det|>
What could be changed so that the rod moves to the left?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 411, 134, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 411, 292, 428]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 437, 131, 456]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 437, 722, 456]]<|/det|>
Reverse the battery terminals and exchange the poles of the magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 464, 133, 482]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 464, 796, 482]]<|/det|>
Reverse the battery terminals but without exchanging the poles of the magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 489, 133, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 489, 556, 507]]<|/det|>
Turn the metal rod around (P and Q exchanged).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 533, 104, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 533, 806, 551]]<|/det|>
A transformer in a computer is used to transform the mains voltage of 240 V to 12 V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 536, 581]]<|/det|>
The number of turns on the secondary coil is 2000.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 593, 532, 611]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the transformer is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 621, 133, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 621, 697, 640]]<|/det|>
It is a step-down transformer and has 100 turns on its primary coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 649, 133, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 649, 720, 667]]<|/det|>
It is a step-down transformer and has 40 000 turns on its primary coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 133, 693]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 675, 675, 693]]<|/det|>
It is a step-up transformer and has 100 turns on its primary coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 700, 133, 719]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 700, 695, 719]]<|/det|>
It is a step-up transformer and has 40 000 turns on its primary coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 744, 106, 762]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 744, 532, 762]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 774, 534, 792]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 804, 348, 822]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 833, 134, 851]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 833, 408, 851]]<|/det|>
Atom P has atomic number 12.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 860, 133, 878]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 860, 408, 878]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 887, 133, 905]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 887, 420, 905]]<|/det|>
Atom Q has nucleon number 13.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 912, 133, 930]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 912, 549, 930]]<|/det|>
Atoms P and Q are different chemical elements.

<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 813, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 710, 106, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 710, 922, 745]]<|/det|>
A scientist carries out an experiment using a sealed source which emits \(\beta \text {-particles.}\) The range of the \(\beta \text {-particles}\) in the air is about \(30 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 756, 777, 775]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 785, 133, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 785, 448, 803]]<|/det|>
handling the source with long tongs

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 812, 133, 829]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 812, 500, 829]]<|/det|>
keeping the temperature of the source low

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 839, 133, 857]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 574, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 144, 116]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 138, 170]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 106, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 470, 241]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the Sun is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 250, 133, 268]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 250, 700, 268]]<|/det|>
The Sun is a dwarf star consisting mostly of hydrogen and oxygen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 277, 133, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 277, 734, 295]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 303, 133, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 303, 767, 320]]<|/det|>
